title: 1-D Illustration of LDA vs QDA with {distributional}
text:
So, three things happened this week that inspired this tidbit:

I learned about the {distributional} package by â€¦ at the UseR 2024 conference, which basically defines distributions as their own objects, to be plotted or used in calculations. Very cool!
I was reminded in a conversation recently that {gganimate} is cool and something Iâ€™d like to use more in classes.
A student asked me why QDA can lead to circular boundaries and LDA canâ€™t, when the only difference is whether we let the covariance vary by group. I answered by very badly drawing a series of pictures in the 1-D case.

So my goal here is to re-create those pictures as a gif.

library(tidyverse)
library(distributional)
library(gganimate)

Alright, first thing is to figure out plotting two normal distributions using {distributional}

my_dists <- c(dist_normal(mu = 0, sigma = 1), 
              dist_normal(mu = 3, sigma = 1))

my_dists

<distribution[2]>
[1] N(0, 1) N(3, 1)


DISTRIBUTIONS AS OBJECTS my people I am so pleased with this structure.
Okay hang on apparently we need ggdist too to plot itâ€¦ whoa I donâ€™t think I realized how awesome and built-out ggdist is.
Anyways now itâ€™s super easyâ€¦

library(ggdist)

ggplot(my_dists) +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dist))

Error in `fortify()`:
! `data` must be a <data.frame>, or an object coercible by `fortify()`,
  or a valid <data.frame>-like object coercible by `as.data.frame()`.
Caused by error in `.prevalidate_data_frame_like_object()`:
! `dim(data)` must return an <integer> of length 2.


OOPS, famous last words. Of course my objects still need to be in a data frameâ€¦ duh, Kelly.

my_df <- tibble(
  dist = c(dist_normal(mu = 0, sigma = 1), 
              dist_normal(mu = 3, sigma = 1))
)


ggplot(my_df) +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dist))








Okay cool but itâ€™s sideways and also I need colors. (Side note, itâ€™s annoying that â€œdistributionâ€ and â€œdistanceâ€ are both super common stat words and they have the same natural abbreviation. Rabble rabble.)
A little noodling and cheating with coord flip (there was probably a better way to get these on the x-axis) and I have what I want for now:

my_df <- tibble(
  dist = c(dist_normal(mu = 0, sigma = 1), 
              dist_normal(mu = 3, sigma = 1)),
  name = c("Class A", "Class B")
)


ggplot(my_df) +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dist,
                        fill = name),
                    alpha = 0.5) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position="none")








Now we add the lines to show where the decision boundary for LDA would be (assuming equal prior probs here):

ggplot(my_df) +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dist,
                        fill = name),
                    alpha = 0.5) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position="none") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 1.5) 








I kinda feel like I should be able to use geom_vline after coord_flip and have it not get flipped because it comes as a later layer. Rabble, rabble.
Anyhoo. Now to animate.
This is a little weird to think about because gganimate wants to step through â€œstateâ€ or values in the data. I think I maybe want to set it up as two separate layers, one with the static blue curve and one with the moving red ones.

my_df <- tibble(
  means = (-8:8)/2,
  dists = dist_normal(mu = means, sigma = 1),
)

ggplot(my_df) +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dists),
                    alpha = 0.5,
                    fill = "#F8766D") +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dist_normal(mu = 0, sigma = 1)),
                    alpha = 0.5,
                    fill = "#00BFC4") +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position="none") +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept = (means)/2))

Warning in layer_slabinterval(data = data, mapping = mapping, stat = StatSlabinterval, : All aesthetics have length 1, but the data has 17 rows.
â„¹ Please consider using `annotate()` or provide this layer with data containing
  a single row.









Now I gotta remember how you gganimate a plot. I think you add a layer with some kind of animate_ function?

Ok cool got it:

anim <-
  ggplot(my_df) +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dists),
                    alpha = 0.5,
                    fill = "#F8766D") +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dist_normal(mu = 0, sigma = 1)),
                    alpha = 0.5,
                    fill = "#00BFC4") +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position="none") +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept = (means)/2)) +
  transition_manual(means)

animate(anim)








Et voila! What weâ€™re seeing here is that if the curves have the same variance, they can only ever cross at one point. (Well, unless they have the exact same mean and have infinite overlap, but if thatâ€™s the case then LDA is pointless anyways.)
So now what if we let them have different variances? Weâ€™ll try one for starters:

my_df <- tibble(
  means = -1,
  dists = dist_normal(mu = means, sigma = 3),
)

ggplot(my_df) +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dists),
                    alpha = 0.5,
                    fill = "#F8766D") +
  stat_dist_halfeye(data = NULL, aes(dist = dist_normal(mu = 0, sigma = 1)),
                    alpha = 0.5,
                    fill = "#00BFC4") +
  scale_thickness_shared() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position="none") 








Okay scale_thickness_shared() ended up being really important here to keep the curves from being the same height (and thus different areas, ew).
Finding the intersection point is more of a pain than I thought about at first, because Normal equations are not really closed-form solvable. But distributional makes this not TOO bad at least.

my_df <- tibble(
  means = (-8:8)/2,
  dists = dist_normal(mu = means, sigma = 3),
)

std_normal <- dist_normal(mu = 0, sigma = 1)

grid <- seq(-10, 10, 0.1)
std_dens <- density(std_normal, grid)[[1]]

crosslines <-
  my_df$dists |>
  density(grid) |>
  map(\(dens) order(abs(dens/std_dens - 1))[1:2]) |>
  map(\(idx) sort(grid[idx])) |>
  reduce(rbind)

my_df <- 
  my_df |>
  mutate(
    lower = crosslines[,1],
    upper = crosslines[,2]
  )

Phew. That took some doing actually.
BUT! The part you should be excited about here is my_df$dists |> density(grid). Likeâ€¦. that vectorization is elegant af.
Anyways. Cool. Hereâ€™s a gif.

anim <-
  ggplot(my_df) +
  stat_dist_halfeye(aes(dist = dists),
                    alpha = 0.5,
                    fill = "#F8766D") +
  stat_dist_halfeye(data = NULL, aes(dist = dist_normal(mu = 0, sigma = 1)),
                    alpha = 0.5,
                    fill = "#00BFC4") +
  scale_thickness_shared() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position="none") +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept = lower)) +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept = upper)) +
  transition_manual(means)

animate(anim)








Boom! Two points of intersection, which lets you segment the space such that blue class is â€œinsideâ€ and red class is â€œoutsideâ€.
If you can mental-image this up to two dimensions, maybe you can see how equal-variance bell curves intersect at a straight line, and nonequal-variance onces can have an â€œinner circleâ€ and â€œouter circleâ€, hence LDA vs QDA.
The end!
If I were using this in class, Iâ€™d probably add:

Some sample observations, to show that in LDA/QDA these curves are the estimates we get based on observed data, not something we magically know ahead of time.
Some background coloring or arrows or something to clarify that the boundaries are prediction boundaries; we predict red or blue class based on where a new observation lands.
Some aesthetic dressing up: Nice outlines on the curves, a star or something at the density intersection, better colors than red-blue, etc.

title: Notes from Posit::conf session on Quarto
text:

David Keyes: Making pretty reports

Use functions to make plots consistent.

else p <- p + <different layer option>

title: First thoughts on Positron
text:
This is a very disorganized list of notes I made trying out Positron for the first time. Hopefully some slightly more coherent updates will come along eventually as I use it more and/or it updates.
Working directories: I thought I would hate the â€œopen a folderâ€ workflow (as opposed to opening a .RProj) but actually Iâ€™m vibing with it. Itâ€™s especially nice for one-off tasks, e.g.Â when I use R to calculate an exam curve. I never quite liked choosing between a â€œfloatingâ€ qmd or a one-time-use R Project.



Folders behave like projects.


That said, my work didnâ€™t â€œfeelâ€ like a project. I like having all the RStudio windows open in my dock so I can project hop. Relatedly - I crash R all the time, and I like that it only crashes the instance Iâ€™m in; does using Positron mean that if I crash things, all my projects close?



RRRRRRRRRR


Quarto: The â€œnew notebookâ€ shortcut on the landing page makes a Jupyter doc not a Quarto doc. Booo. Plus thereâ€™s NO RENDER BUTTON for Quarto docs. Ew. Worst,thereâ€™s no inline preview option in Quarto yet, which is a major dealbreaker for now. Iâ€™m told these things will be added; but for now Positron is not super optimized for Quarto.



This opens a new ipynb.


Chunks: The chunk shortcut is different. Thatâ€™s fine, I think itâ€™s PC/Mac consistent now. I do like the drop-down language options when you add a chunkâ€¦ except that after the first chunk I donâ€™t want to have to â€œconfirmâ€ my language choice every time. The â€œrun this chunkâ€ play button is IMHO better, although breaking my muscle memory has been hard.



Snazzy, but now I have to hit â€œenterâ€ every time I make a new chunk.


Panes: I donâ€™t like having the variables pane at the bottom, and then it disappears if you switch tabs at top. I like being able to see my environment at all times regardless of what help tab Iâ€™m in.
 
Files: I like having notification badges for unsaved files. Itâ€™s also just a lot easier to navigate between files in general.



I love having the Explorer on the left!


Help: The dynamic suggestions are coolâ€¦ but floating helpers are in my way. I like the info but itâ€™s in my way enough that I would turn this off - Iâ€™d rather have some kind of permanent help text location in a corner that I can glance at when I need it.



Itâ€™s just kind of an excessive amount of pop-up and itâ€™s blocking my pipeline.

title: paRticles
text:
One of my resolutions right now is to be better about putting things out into the internet world, without feeling like they need to be polished or perfect or full of lots of content.
I already have a mostly unused blog as well as some long-form posts on other blogs and Iâ€™ll probably stick to those places when I manage to write things that are, you know, thorough and carefully edited over weeks. But probably my favorite thing Iâ€™ve ever put out into the internet world is this unhinged stream-of-consciousness about trying to learn NSE, and I want to get more comfortable with that kind of in-the-moment micro post.
So: here is where Iâ€™ll try to put quick ideas, discoveries, and little things that I figure out or think are cool. Welcome to paRticles!
